I actually could fit two weeks worth of clothes for my 5 year old since her things are smaller.  We are staying 3 weeks at grandma's house so we do laundrythere. date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
review_content: I purchased this suitcase because of a week long trip across the country with VERY different weather than mine, so I had to pack more than t-shirts and shorts.  This suitcase is deceiving - it looks smaller than what it actually is and I DID have room to spare.  I did use packing cubes because it is helpful to me, but I did manage to get a week's worth of clothing (no access to washing machine) that included 3 t-shirts, 2 leggings, 3 blouses, 3 camisoles, a light sweater, jeans, 2 pairs of shoes (1 was heels, the other was flats), and undergarments.  My clothes did not come out all wrinkled or incredibly creased - not more than you would get from folding your clothes and putting them in a drawer.  The empty space that is in there contained a makeup bag and the TSA approved baggie of toiletries.The small carry on was a bit more disappointing - a lot could be stuck in there, but regardless of size or weight of the items, it seemed to pull at the seams in a few different spots.  It is completely functional, though.  The zipper got stuck a couple of times, but I can't blame the making of the bag for this alone.Regarding sizing and durability, the suitcase itself does comply and fit into one of those 14" x 22" sizing things at the airport.  The smaller bag fits perfectly under the seats.  This suitcase went on 7 flights, including 2 that had to be valet checked because of the size of the aircraft and even wound up in the wing of a Cessna at one point.  It has a couple of dirt scuffs, but it is in otherwise perfect shape!One thing to note - if you put something (like sandals) in the front pouch of the larger one, it will topple over.  I do wish the base was sturdier, but I can't complain too much with the pricing of it.  I've read a couple reviews where it says it smells.  Yes, it is a bit smelly out of the box, but it is the smell as if it sat in a box in a warehouse.  If you let it air out, the smell goes away.Definitely a good combo and worth the price!

author: L. Mountford
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2017
review_content: I've owned a Rockland wheeled duffle for a number of years and LOVE it.  Great quality, easy to pack and wheel around, I've taken it on at least a dozen trips on planes as well as Amtrak cross-country trips.  It still looks almost like new.So when I went looking for a small-ish wheeled carry-on bag w/ tote, I immediately came to Rockland.  For the price point, I wasn't expecting super great quality.  This set isn't horrible, but I would never want to check it, though -- I don't think it would ever stand up to even moderately rough treatment.The biggest problem is the wheeled carry-on bag.  It doesn't stand up by itself when packed.  It looks like it's supposed to, but the "stand" part near the front isn't sturdy or big enough to balance the bag.  So if you stop anywhere, you have to make sure you lean it against your leg or something.  REALLY annoying.  Also, it doesn't balance well on the wheels, so if you're pulling it through the airport, it flops over sideways.I think I'll be more likely to use this for short 2- to 4-day road trips, where I just dump it into the car and don't have to worry about wheeling it over long distances in an airport.The shoulder bag is OK, but the strap isn't really long enough for an adult, even fully extended.  Again, this is likely something I'll use for shorter road trips.Meanwhile, I'll keep looking for a decent carry-on bag set, and increase my budget.  This is ... just OK.

review_content: Unfortunately I had to cancel the trip I bought the suitcase for and only just discovered that it was defective, after the return window closed. Looking behind the zipper that reveals the handle mechanism inside the larger suitcase, I found that the lowest pin on one side of the tube that carries the handle was not retracting when the button on top of the handle was pushed. The handle button pushed in easily but the handle still couldn't be pulled out.So I did this procedure:1)  I folded 3/4 inch wide electrical tape onto itself several times, cut it from the roll, and then bent my little "plug" of tape in half to make a shape that fit well nside the oval opening in the metal tube.2)  I wrapped the folded piece in one inch of tape in the folded position to keep the lump/plug  bent and smooth.3) I cut a 2 inch piece of tape and  a 3/4 inch piece. I used the 3/4 inch piece to secure my plug to the middle of the sticky side of the 2 inch piece (the plug was perpendicular to the 2 inch piece of tape).4) Finally, I wrapped the tube with the 2 inch piece, making sure the plug fit well and snuggly into the hole.  While wrapping the tube, I made sure to stretch the tape a bit to make sure it fit tightly against the hole in the tube.So far it's working, although the Youtuber said it's only a temporary fix. I'm not changing the review stars since this problem shouldn't have existed in the first place, but maybe someone can benefit from these instructions if they have the same problem.Otherwise the suitcase, as I said before, is beautiful.
